messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level B1

Text saved: Sometimes, we do not know why a bridge collapses. Engineers only understand the reason after they study the situation completely. In some cases, a collapse happens because builders used bad materials. It can also happen because there was a problem with an important part of the bridge. In other situations, the bridge was designed to carry only a certain amount of weight and not more.

metadata.feedback_text: The submission fails because it uses a B2-level word, 'collapse', without defining it in the keywords section. The B1 assessment protocol is clear: 'Unexplained advanced vocabulary is a failure.' While the text demonstrates several B1 competencies, this violation of the core vocabulary rule is a critical error. On a positive note, the text shows a strong ability to paraphrase complex ideas into simpler B1 language. For example, replacing 'inferior-quality material' with 'bad material' and 'a defect in a key piece' with 'a problem with an important part' are excellent demonstrations of B1-level communicative skill. The use of connectors is also appropriate for this level, as seen in the sentence '...because bad material was used, or...there was a problem...'. The overall structure is coherent and factually accurate. To achieve a passing grade, the writer must ensure all vocabulary is within the B1 core, or any necessary B2 words are explicitly defined as keywords.
